content.webTitle: Good to Meet You: Keith Langton

fields.headline: Good to Meet You: Keith Langton
fields.bodyText: I've been reading The Guardian since my late teens. I wouldn't consider buying another newspaper. I teach media studies to 11- to 16-year-olds in Basingstoke, and I find that although I have to buy all of the dailies when I talk to my students about newspapers, I quickly discard the others. The mix of writers who are not afraid to rattle cages, entertaining articles and excellent photography is what appeals to me. I often agree with the editorial politics, but as a life-long socialist I could not bring myself to vote Lib-Dem last year, as backed by the Guardian, and I think others might agree that I was correct in my opinion. I'm now 50 and I live in Finchampstead, near Wokingham with my wife Lyn and our three lovely cats. My likes have changed little over the years – music, books and film, cricket and football – so I enjoy Mike Selvey for his cricket writing and Pete Bradshaw's no-nonsense film reviews. When I first started reading the paper, I worshipped Nancy Banks-Smith and Matthew Engel – so much so that I once asked Engel to sign a cricket scorecard for me at a match. He was very non-plussed, and asked if I was sure I knew who he was. What to improve? As a tech-phile, I miss Thursday's technology section. And as a life-long supporter of League One Brentford, I have to say that your lower-league football coverage is pretty awful. Don't people ever get tired of reading about the overpaid primadonnas of the Premiership?
